Ye Dryads, who woo the recess</br>Where the oak's ample shadow extends,</br>To your haunts of retirement I press,</br>And the muse my intrusion attends.</br>From the morning too brilliant I stray,</br>From the solar meridian blaze,</br>When mute is the chorister's lay,</br>And the sun darts his vertical rays.

Retirement, how sweet is thy pow'r!</br>I fly from the indolent breeze;</br>I fly from the hot-parching hour;</br>Receive me, ye gloom-shedding trees.</br>With you lonely silence prevails,</br>You shelter my Celadon's seat,</br>Whose cot no ambition assails,</br>Except to be honest and neat.

No sycophant here shall be heard,</br>Where Friendship her quietude seeks,</br>Sincerity utters the word</br>From the lips of Veracity speaks.</br>What tho' in this temperate scite,</br>This hermitage, hidden and mean,</br>No pane of high polish the light</br>Reflects to illumine the scene;

What tho' on the unadorn'd wall</br>Shall sculpture her chissel deny!</br>No portal conduct to the hall,</br>Where paintings replenish the eye!</br>Yet here, in profusion of sweets,</br>Calm Solitude leads by the hand</br>The hind that Felicity meets,</br>And scorns every wish to be grand.

The gay fascination of wealth</br>No envy to Celadon brings,</br>Be his but contentment and health,</br>With pity he looks down on kings.</br>Secure from vexation and strife,</br>Devotion sheds balm on his breast;</br>How smooth is that tenor of life,</br>Where conscience strews poppies of rest.

The amaranth has not deny'd</br>The eglantine's blossoms to join;</br>The lily, high rising in pride,</br>Her silver extols to the vine.</br>The boughs of the apple and pear</br>A canopy mutually form,</br>His cottage from perils to spare,</br>When rises the war of the storm.

E'en now clouds collecting behold,</br>Whose darkness conceals the sun's light,</br>Tho' noon yet what horrors unfold!</br>Present an unseasonable night.</br>The thunder, impressive of pain,</br>Rolls awful solemnity round;</br>Thro' clouds it reverb'rates again;</br>Re-echoes the dread-striking sound.

How dark and how dismal the scene!</br>Now rushes in torrents the rain;</br>Red flashes of fate intervene,</br>How shakes with convulsions the plain!</br>Let elements wildly contend,</br>Tho' the aether dissolve in a blaze;</br>To the breast of my unappall'd friend,</br>Their fury no trouble conveys.

The terrible concert is o'er,</br>Hush'd all its unfortunate rage;</br>Great Ruler to thee let me pour</br>The thanks which my bosom engage.</br>The tempest is o'er, and the sun</br>Descends with his Thetis to rest,</br>If e'er by my theme thou wert won,</br>Come, Delia, sole queen of my breast.

Lo!  Ev'ning, mild daughter of Day,</br>In aspect as thee, most serene,</br>Her smiles shall enliven my lay,</br>So calm and unclouded her mien.</br>The lark to her nestlings descends,</br>The wood deepens faster to brown;</br>To the village the cottager bends,</br>The village that's sought by the town.

The flocks and the herds are at large,</br>Their coverts of coolness they leave</br>To taste of the rills blady marge,</br>And share the soft gifts of the eve.</br>The swallow, in search of his prey,</br>Skims lightly o'er thistle and brake,</br>Glides swift as for plunder, or prey,</br>His wings dash the wave of the lake.

How bright are the smiles of the youth,</br>Where summer perpetually reigns!</br>Thou gem of original truth,</br>Shall we join in the dance on the plains?</br>Thro' the fields where the purple-ey'd tare</br>Blooms lavish thy presence to greet:</br>To the glade of refreshment repair,</br>Where offers the moss-cushion'd seat.

To gain a repast for the eye,</br>Yon eminence shall we explore;</br>There, Delia, together descry</br>The streamers that crimson the shore,</br>Till the view by gradation shall fade,</br>The ev'ning's late shadows prevail,</br>And Cynthia soft mantles in shade,</br>Full orb'd, tells her wonderful tale.

Thou pride of my pastoral lay,</br>Dear maid of my uniform love,</br>Soon the morn of the bright summer's day,</br>And its noon must to ev'ning remove.</br>Whose bliss-giving shadows are fled,</br>But soon shall the morning renew;</br>Her charms that no longer are spread,</br>To paint the magnificent view.

How like is the portrait of man:</br>The morn of his infancy fades,</br>The race of his manhood soon ran,</br>And age sinks in death's night of shades.</br>But like welcome morning's return,</br>Re-born the sunk mortal shall rise,</br>In triumph shall burst from the urn,</br>And beam in the bliss of the skies.</br>
